problem_text: Suppose that a and b are two elements of a finite group G such that the function φ(g) = 1G(g) − 1G⟨a⟩(g) − 1G⟨b⟩(g) − 1G⟨ab⟩(g) + 2 is a character of G. Is it true that G = ⟨a, b⟩? The converse statement is true. S. P. Strunkov
answer: No, not always: a counterexample is given by G = A4, a = b = (123). (S. V. Skresanov, Algebra Logic, 58, no. 3 (2019), 249–253).
